metadata.case_name: Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant appointed to Indian Police Service in 1935.
Appellant posted as Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh on 1 November 1956.
Appellant confirmed as Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh in 1957.
Appellant reached age of 55 years on 14 May 1966 but continued as IGP Andhra Pradesh up to 1 August 1967.
Appellant posted as Special Inspector General of Police for revision of Police Standing Orders after 1 August 1967.
In 1967, Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh ordered Chief Secretary to enquire into certain allegations against appellant.
Chief Secretary recommended requesting Vigilance Commissioner, Andhra Pradesh to look into the matter.
Vigilance Commissioner advised enquiry by independent agency like Central Bureau of Investigation.
Central Bureau of Investigation conducted enquiry; appellant given allegations to answer, submitted explanation, and was examined.
Central Bureau of Investigation made a report on the enquiry.
First Information Report dated 17 August 1967 under section 154 CrPC charging appellant with offences under Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 for period 1960 to 1967.

Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs made order on 11 July 1968 placing appellant under suspension, reciting serious allegations of corruption and malpractice, prima facie case from CBI enquiry, and satisfaction that it is necessary and desirable.
Delhi High Court judgment and order dated 17 April 1969 in Civil Writ No. 611 of 1968 upholding suspension.
Appellant alleged Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh inimical since General Elections 1967.
Appellant alleged CBI investigation conducted by hostile persons.
Appellant alleged Ministry of Home Affairs relied on mala fide report initiated by Chief Minister.
Affidavits filed by parties, including appellant's, not verified.
Criminal investigation, inquiry or trial relating to criminal charge pending against appellant.
Appellant raised contention as to vires of Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946 and validity of investigation, but did not press in this appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of suspension was passed on a report made mala fide, rendering it bad.
Whether the order of suspension was made under sub-rule 1 of Rule 7 of All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955 without disciplinary proceedings initiated, liable to be quashed.
Whether the order of suspension is in infraction of Rule 7.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of suspension passed on report made mala fide by Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh (inimical since 1967 elections) and hostile CBI investigators; Ministry of Home Affairs should not have relied on it.
Order made under sub-rule 1 of Rule 7 without disciplinary proceedings initiated and Government satisfaction as required.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 7(1), All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: Not suspended under sub-rule 3 of Rule 7.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 7(3), All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: Vires of Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946 and validity of investigation.

respondent_arguments.text: Produced copy of First Information Report dated 17 August 1967 under s.154 CrPC for offences under Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.154 CrPC; Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947

court_reasoning.text: Pre-eminent question is whether suspension order in infraction of Rule 7; Rule 7(1) for disciplinary proceedings, Rule 7(2) for criminal charges pending.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order recites serious allegations, prima facie case from CBI, satisfaction necessary; read in context of FIR and pending criminal investigation, falls under Rule 7(3).

court_reasoning.text: Appellant failed to establish mala fides; no specific allegation against GoI officers; Chief Minister not party; affidavits unverified hence inadmissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To succeed on mala fides, must prove order mala fide or for collateral purposes; neither alleged nor established.

court_reasoning.text: CBI report not to be examined for correctness; order warranted by rule and honest exercise of power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government applied mind to allegations, enquiries, circumstances.

court_reasoning.text: No opinion on merits of charges as criminal case pending.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contention on Delhi Special Police Act left open for criminal trial.

holdings.text: Order of suspension made under sub-rule 3 of Rule 7 and does not suffer from infringement of Rule 7.
No mala fides established against Government of India.
Unverified affidavits inadmissible; importance of verification to test genuineness.

statutes_cited.name: All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs suspension: (1) pending disciplinary proceedings if necessary; (2) pending criminal investigation/inquiry/trial at discretion if connected to duties or moral turpitude. Order valid under (3).

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged against appellant in FIR.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Vires and validity of investigation questioned but left open.

outcome.summary: Appeal challenging suspension order dismissed; order held valid under Rule 7(3) as criminal investigation pending; no mala fides proved; contention on Delhi Special Police Act left open.

key_quotes.text: The order of suspension has to be read in the context of the entire case and combination of circumstances.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies interpreting suspension under Rule 7(3) despite no explicit reference.

key_quotes.text: In essence verification is required to enable the Court to find out as to whether it will be safe to act on such affidavit evidence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains rejection of unverified affidavits supporting mala fides claim.

key_quotes.text: The appellant has failed to establish that the Government acted mala fide.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding dismissing primary ground of challenge.
